message: Participants receive lifetime access to 18 hours of live, interactive sessions, 10 hours of step-by-step coding instructions, a final project with direct feedback, 100 coding assignments and practice questions, the entire source code of a working production system, access to a private community, direct access to the instructor, lifetime access to every past and future cohort, and a program certificate upon completion.
Yes, the live sessions of the program are recorded.
The cost to join the program is $500 and it includes lifetime access to every past, present, and future cohort.
There is a one-time fee of $500 to join the program, with no monthly fees, annual fees, or hidden costs.
The next cohort for the 'Building Machine Learning Systems That Don't Suck' program is on February 3 - 20, 2025.
The strategies mentioned for active learning in the course include uncertainty and diversity sampling strategies.

You'll come out with practical skills and insights into what it takes to build systems that work in the real world. Some of the skills you will gain include designing and writing code to build an end-to-end machine learning system from scratch, learning best practices to tackle challenges faced by machine learning engineers, and using techniques like active learning, distributed training, adversarial validation, human-in-the-loop deployments, model compression, and test-time augmentation.
Juan Olano
You only pay once to join the program and get immediate access to every past, present, and future cohort.

The program's live sessions for building machine learning systems include 18 hours of live, interactive sessions, 10 hours of step-by-step coding instructions, and opportunities to practice with 100 coding assignments.

To enroll in the program, one must pay a one-time fee of $500. There are no monthly fees, annual fees, or hidden costs associated with joining the program. Once the payment is made, participants will have lifetime access to every past, present, and future cohort of the program, as well as all the resources and benefits included in the program.

Upon enrollment in the machine learning program, the following resources and benefits are provided:

1. 18 hours of live, interactive sessions
2. 10 hours of step-by-step coding instructions
3. A final project with direct feedback
4. 100 coding assignments and practice questions
5. The entire source code of a working production system
6. Access to a private community for collaboration
7. Direct access to the instructor
8. Lifetime access to past and future cohorts
9. Program certificate upon completion
10. Ability to start freelancing on Upwork
11. Feedback and support from the community
12. Unique opportunity to learn from an instructor with over two decades of experience in building and scaling enterprise software and machine learning systems
13. Lifetime access to all program materials and updates
14. Exclusive materials such as the source code of a working production system and practical coding instructions
15. No restrictions on usage or access to the program resources

These resources and benefits highlight the practical, hands-on learning approach of the program, providing participants with the necessary tools and support to build machine learning systems effectively.

You'll come out with practical skills and insights into what it takes to build systems that work in the real world. You'll design and write the code to build an end-to-end machine learning system starting from scratch. You'll learn best practices to tackle the most significant challenges machine learning engineers face to build, evaluate, run, monitor, and maintain machine learning systems in real-world scenarios.

The upcoming Cohort 17 of the program will start on February 3, 2025, and end on February 20, 2025. The live sessions will take place every Monday and Thursday at 10:00 AM EST. On Wednesdays, there will be optional office hours for participants to bring their questions or projects for discussion. The weekly schedule for Cohort 17 is as follows:
- Monday: Live session for 2 hours
- Tuesday: Individual work
- Wednesday: Optional office hours
- Thursday: Live session for 2 hours
- Friday: Individual work
The copyright is registered under Tideily LLC and the contact email provided is svpino@gmail.com. All rights are reserved.

Session 1 of the program focuses on key subjects related to production machine learning and project initiation strategies. Some of the main topics discussed include:
- The differences between production machine learning and theoretical learning.
- Strategies to solve the right problem using the right solution.
- Critical questions to ask before starting any project.
- Techniques for problem framing, inversion, and the haystack principle for building successful applications.
- The first rule of machine learning engineering and how to start building.
- Data collection strategies and determining the amount of data needed.
- Dealing with selection bias in data.
- Labeling data using human annotations, natural labels, and weak supervision.
- Active learning strategies using uncertainty and diversity sampling.
Overall, Session 1 provides a comprehensive overview of the initial steps and considerations involved in starting a machine learning project geared towards production applications.
You can access recordings of the live sessions from the Machine Learning School program if you are unable to attend the sessions live and wish to catch up asynchronously later.
The strategies for active learning highlighted in the course include uncertainty sampling and diversity sampling.

The exact start date for the upcoming cohort of the 'Building Machine Learning Systems That Don't Suck' program is February 3, 2025. The cohort will run from February 3 to February 20, 2025, with live sessions taking place every Monday and Thursday at 10:00 AM EST. On Wednesdays, there will be testing in production and other activities.

Those interested in implementing the concepts discussed in class should set aside 2 to 4 hours weekly to complete the code walkthroughs and work on the assignments.

Participants in the program mentioned in the context will gain practical skills in building machine learning systems. These skills include problem-solving strategies, data collection techniques, coding instructions, and the ability to start and complete a project from scratch. Additionally, participants will have access to a supportive community, feedback from instructors, and the opportunity to work on real-world assignments. The program's emphasis on inclusivity and accessibility ensures that all participants, including those with disabilities, have the opportunity to learn and succeed in the field of machine learning.
The strategies covered in the course for active learning include uncertainty and diversity sampling strategies to address selection bias and ensure data diversity.

Yes, in the context of the program, 'lifetime access' means that participants will have ongoing access to all course materials and updates, even if they are unable to complete the program due to unforeseen circumstances.

For someone who prefers to watch recorded sessions at their own pace, they can access the recorded session of the first session and learn about these topics at their convenience. They can pause, rewind, and rewatch the session as needed to fully understand the concepts discussed. Additionally, with lifetime access to the program, they can revisit the session anytime in the future for a refresher.

The topics covered in Session 2 of the course on the Machine Learning School Website include data cleaning, feature engineering, turning data into numbers using vectorization techniques, normalization and standardization of features, handling missing values with imputation techniques, choosing the best model for a problem, overfitting, hyperparameter tuning, and measuring the quality of holdout sets.
You only pay once to join the program and get immediate access to every past, present, and future cohort. The cost is $500 for lifetime access with no monthly fees, annual fees, or hidden costs.

Some of the key benefits offered by the program include lifetime access to past and future cohorts, 18 hours of live interactive sessions, 10 hours of step-by-step coding instructions, 100 coding assignments, access to the complete source code of a production system, feedback and support from the community, and direct feedback from the instructor.

- Problem framing, inversion, and the haystack principle for building successful applications
- The first rule of machine learning engineering and how to start building
